title: Why Riven Q?
body: I just started playing Riven, she is pretty strong and pretty fun to play tho not without her share of risks. The only problem is, why does she Q in the direction she is facing? This has to be the most counter-intuitive thing ever, you have your cursor somewhere you press Q and u go in a complete direction, of course not always, like if your are already facing in the right direction or have cursor over enemy you'll hit at the right place, I'm aware of but still... I mean 99% of skills work the other way around, I wish someone had a good reason to explain this mechanic so I could say like ''HAAAAAAAAA! That's why!''. Any thought on that? Should they change it you think?

replies.body:
IIRC she was designed that way before they figured out how to program champs to jump towards cursor.  You can look at the pre-rework Nidalee vs the reworked Nidalee for an example here.

There is an advantage to it in my eyes - you can move in a direction with Broken Wings without your mouse cursor being in that direction, which allows you to quickly click to move in a different direction or cast Valor to dash there.

I think for the most part Riven mains (myself included) prefer that she Q in the direction she faces.  Part of the skill for playing her comes down to your ability to aim her dashes properly.

> IIRC she was designed that way before they figured out how to program champs to jump towards cursor.

Then why has her E shield always jumped in the direction of the cursor?

> > IIRC she was designed that way before they figured out how to program champs to jump towards cursor.
> 
> Then why has her E shield always jumped in the direction of the cursor?

i'm pretty sure it doesn't. i often use my E to line up wall jumps so that i don't have to click directly next to a wall and i never put my cursor on the other side of the wall when i E-Q to jump it.

> There is an advantage to it in my eyes - you can move in a direction with Broken Wings without your mouse cursor being in that direction, which allows you to quickly click to move in a different direction or cast Valor to dash there.

That could indeed be an advantage but a very small one.

> I think for the most part Riven mains (myself included) prefer that she Q in the direction she faces.  

You probably prefer that because you are used to playing her that way, if it has always been the other way you'd probably find it very awkward.

>Part of the skill for playing her comes down to your ability to aim her dashes properly.

Yeah I agree 100%, but if we consider it counter-intuitive (and it is, since all other skills work the other way around), it means that they added a useless difficulty in the skill.

> > 
> > Then why has her E shield always jumped in the direction of the cursor?
> 
> **i'm pretty sure it doesn't.** i always **use my E to line up wall jumps** so that i don't have to click directly next to a wall and i never put my cursor on the other side of the wall when i E-Q to jump it.

Are you sure you main her, because that's exactly how her E works, and besides that, and I might be wrong there, Riven can either go trough very few walls with her E or not at all, since I wasn't able to go trough any of the wall I tried going trough with it.

> Are you sure you main her, because that's exactly how her E works, and besides that, and I might be wrong there, Riven can either go trough very few walls with her E or not at all, since I wasn't able to go trough any of the wall I tried going trough with it.

she doesn't go through the wall with her E.  You E->Q because the E puts you right up against it.  The final Q hop has a very short length so if you aren't right up against the wall you can sometimes miss the hop. Throwing the E in is an easy way to guarantee that you don't miss it by accident.  Really useful in situations where you're getting chased down and you can't afford to miss a hop.

and maybe you're right regarding cursor and valor. i'm just always spam clicking when I Valor because using it stops her movement entirely so you have to input another action immediately anyways.

Alright, if you want a good reason for it.

- Let's say you're running away from someone and being chased, you're both extremely low health, if they catch you, you die, shield/w/flash on cd, but ignite is up and they are gaining on you. You can mouse over them, and use ignite, while Q-ing to keep building distance, thus kiting them and letting them die.

- Let's say you want to juke someone with flash. You Q towards the dragon pit, but rather than hopping into it, you want to flash in a bush near it. If you moved towards your cursor, your enemy would be able to read where you want to flash to, thus, you couldn't do fake-outs with flash.

So, the best answer I can give is that it allows you to aim summoner spells and actives on items, while moving in a different direction, thus allowing more plays to be made.

I get everything you are saying, but why only Riven's Q? Why is it the only spell? Every gap closer, or jump or anything could be like that, but they only made that very skill do that (at my own knowledge anyways). Maybe there is no answer, but I have a hard time understanding why someone would go like ''hey, let's do something weird with Riven's Q instead of attacking where the player's cursor is, she could jump in the direction she is facing'', I just think it makes Riven weird to play at first, if I play her a lot I'll probably get used to it but for now, it just sucks plain and simple.

If you highlight something with your curser and press Q, Riven will attempt to Q that target if they're within range of its hit box. Us riven mains prefer the direction she's facing. Nidalee feels horrible after they "fixed" it on her. Go to a custom game and practice.
